Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Ultrafast dynamics of single nanomagnets in dense arrays

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
ECCS-0801896
H. Schmidt, University of California-Santa Cruz

Objective: The objective of this research is to investigate the dynamic response of single nanomagnets within the type of dense arrays that will be found in applications including magnetic data storage, memory, or biosensor arrays. The approach to this effort will be to use time-resolved magneto-optic Kerr (MOKE) spectroscopy in conjunction with optical near-field resolution to measure magnetization changes of single nanomagnets surrounded by magnets in dense arrays. Pre-commercial prototype samples will be fabricated and provided by the industrial partner, Hitachi Global Storage Technologies (HGST).

Intellectual merit: The dynamic magnetization response is a natural limit for the operating speed of future nanomagnetic devices, and a thorough understanding of both the intrinsic magnetization dynamics as well as the influence of dynamically changing magnetic fields from nearby neighbors is essential to optimize device performance. Here, it is proposed to gain this knowledge by (i) developing time-resolved magnetization detection of a single nanomagnet within a dense array using both far-field and near-field MOKE, and (ii) measuring dynamic magnetic properties of individual metal multilayer nanomagnets in dense arrays with sub-picosecond resolution.

Broader Impact: The collaboration with HGST will ensure rapid translation of the results of this research to commercial magnetic storage devices, resulting in broad societal impact through a paradigm change in the way data are stored. HGST will also provide educational opportunities for students at different levels through summer internships and involvement in sample characterization for the project. In addition, undergraduate students from underrepresented minorities will be recruited to participate in the research.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research was to investigate the dynamic response of single nanomagnets within the type of dense arrays that will be found in applications including magnetic data storage, memory, or biosensor arrays. Optical methods based on time-resolved magneto-optic Kerr (MOKE) spectroscopywere used to measure magnetization changes of single nanomagnets surrounded by magnets in dense arrays. Pre-commercial prototype samples were fabricated and provided by the industrial partner, Hitachi Global Storage Technologies (HGST).

Intellectual merit: The dynamic magnetization response is a natural limit for the operating speed of future nanomagnetic devices, and a thorough understanding of both the intrinsic magnetization dynamics as well as the influence of dynamically changing magnetic fields from nearby neighbors is essential to optimize device performance. In the course of this project, we gained significant new understanding of such processes. Specifically, we fabricated and tested series of CoPd multilayer films with perpendicular anisotropy and varying Co layer thickness and substrate material. We  found strong dependence of magnetization precession frequency on Co layer thickness and substrate material as well as a systematic dependence of anisotropy on both Co layer thickness and substrate material

In addition, we fabricated series of nickel nanomagnets with different configurations, most notably single 150nm diameter magnet surrounded by larger 500nm magnets. We were able to demonstrate a new method to observe single magnets in a dense array using far-field optics based on the size-dependence of the magnetic response.

Finally, we observed unexpected interactions between magnetic and nonmagnetic oscillations in dense arrays of CoPd nanomagnets. Using a specially designed series of nanomagnets fabricated at Hitachi, this new phenomenon remains under investigation.

 Broader Impact: The collaboration with HGST allowed us to provide uniqueeducational opportunities for students at different levels. Specific highlights of activities to ensure broad impact include:

  • significant involvement of undergraduates in research
  • undergraduate student completes thesis project and wins UCSC Undergraduate Research Award
  • Outreach visit to MOKE spectroscopy and nanofabrication labs by COSMOS high school students
  • Industrial collaborator (co-PI Terris) gives seminars in EE211 Nanotechnology class at UCSC
  • New nanofabrication and nanocharacterization lab module created
  • PI taught classes on nanotechnology in COSMOS K-12 summer outreach program

Last Modified: 08/20/2012
Modified by: Holger Schmidt
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this research was to investigate the dynamic response of single nanomagnets within the type of dense arrays that will be found in applications including magnetic data storage, memory, or biosensor arrays. Optical methods based on time-resolved magneto-optic Kerr (MOKE) spectroscopywere used to measure magnetization changes of single nanomagnets surrounded by magnets in dense arrays. Pre-commercial prototype samples were fabricated and provided by the industrial partner, Hitachi Global Storage Technologies (HGST). Intellectual merit: The dynamic magnetization response is a natural limit for the operating speed of future nanomagnetic devices, and a thorough understanding of both the intrinsic magnetization dynamics as well as the influence of dynamically changing magnetic fields from nearby neighbors is essential to optimize device performance. In the course of this project, we gained significant new understanding of such processes. Specifically, we fabricated and tested series of CoPd multilayer films with perpendicular anisotropy and varying Co layer thickness and substrate material. We found strong dependence of magnetization precession frequency on Co layer thickness and substrate material as well as a systematic dependence of anisotropy on both Co layer thickness and substrate material In addition, we fabricated series of nickel nanomagnets with different configurations, most notably single 150nm diameter magnet surrounded by larger 500nm magnets. We were able to demonstrate a new method to observe single magnets in a dense array using far-field optics based on the size-dependence of the magnetic response. Finally, we observed unexpected interactions between magnetic and nonmagnetic oscillations in dense arrays of CoPd nanomagnets. Using a specially designed series of nanomagnets fabricated at Hitachi, this new phenomenon remains under investigation.
